clinical_study.brief_title: Naloxone Auto-injector as a Universal Precaution for Patients With Opioid Substance Use Disorder
clinical_study.official_title: Naloxone Auto-injector as a Universal Precaution for Patients With Opioid Substance Use Disorder

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this pilot-study is to to distribute naloxone auto-injector in a "Universal Precaution" manner to patients with opioid substance use disorder. The objectives are to decrease the number of fatal and nonfatal overdose deaths, to examine and understand the risk factors for serious opioid toxicity and overdose, and to evaluate the unintentional opioid overdose risk utilizing an evidence-based screening questionnaire.

primary_outcome.measure: number of fatal over dose deaths by use of naloxone auto-injector co-prescribing from the University of New Mexico Addiction and Substance Abuse Program (UNM ASAP)
primary_outcome.description: Patients on chronic opioid therapy will be co-prescribed a naloxone-autoinjector rescue kit to decrease the accidental overdose rate associated with these medications.

primary_outcome.measure: number of near fatal overdoses prevented by use of naloxone auto-injector co-prescribing from the University of New Mexico Addiction and Substance Abuse Program (UNM ASAP)
primary_outcome.description: Patients on chronic opioid therapy will be co-prescribed a naloxone-autoinjector rescue kit to decrease the accidental overdose rate associated with these medications.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Patients with opioid substance abuse disorders
arm_group.description: All participants will receive Naloxone autoinjector as a preventative tool for accidental opioid overdose

intervention.description: Naloxone auto-injector is the only product FDA approved and labeled for use by family members or caregivers for emergency therapy and rescue wherever opioids are present. Bystanders of patient are able to provide naloxone when drug overdose occurs.
intervention.arm_group_label: Patients with opioid substance abuse disorders

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- All patients treated with methadone, naltrexone or buprenorphine as medication assisted treatment at the UNM Addiction and Substance Abuse Program (UNM ASAP) aged 18 or older
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who are allergic to naloxone and its inactive ingredients. Inactive ingredients include buffering agents.
- Subjects younger than 18.
- Subjects not being treated at UNM ASAP.
